notesStmt.note: WFC misspells "Beck," writing "Bick" instead. Forbes oversaw the construction of the Cody Trading Company and when the building was completed he was replaced by Jacob Schwoob who had been manager of the Iroquois Hotel in Buffalo, New York, owned by Henry M. Gerrans [See Patrick, pp25-26]. WFC misspells the surname 'DeMaris' as "De Mairs." Charles DeMaris (1833-1914), an early settler in the Big Horn Basin, discovered and developed the hot springs on the western edge of Cody, known as DeMaris Springs. "Russell" was likely George S. Russell who was the carpenter that built most of the initial buildings of the new town of Cody [See Patrick, pp28-29]. W. P. Webster was a machinist by trade and became the Postmaster of Cody in 1900. J. Ross Carpenter (1867-1943) was a land developer and president of the Federal Land & Securities Company. Hudson W. Darrah (1864-1929), a sawmill owner with other business interests in and around the town of Cody. WFC writes "Percell" but the proper spelling is "Purcell." Tom Purcell was a saloon owner [See Buffalo Bill's Town in The Rockies, p63]. A. C. Newton was a local rancher who made donations with WFC to start a public subscription for a bridge over the Shoshone River; Newton donated logs for the construction [See Bonner, pp63,65].

div1.p: Yours recd— I am just as anxious as you are for the mill— Why the people will run us out of the Country if itsit's not built. Try Every body Forbes3— De Mairs4 — Russell5— Webster6 the Mormon Carpenter7. Darrah. Tom Percell8 to take stock— we must build the mill and there is not a day to looselose. You can count on Me for $2000. Now George jump to it. And letslet's get the work started. Wire me Soon as possible what can be done—

postscript.p: I beleivebelieve Newton9 will take $500 or a $1000 worth of stock. If work is commenced. rush it.

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Erie, Pennsylvania, on July 9, 1898.

Note 3: Forbes oversaw the construction of the Cody Trading Company and when the building was completed he was replaced by Jacob M. "Jake" Schwoob who had been manager of the Iroquois Hotel in Buffalo, New York, which was owned by Henry M. Gerrans.
Note 4: "De Mairs" is Cody's misspelling of Charles DeMaris, an early settler in the Big Horn Basin who settled near the warm sulphur springs named for him: DeMaris Springs.
Note 5: "Russell" may be George S. Russell (1850-1922), the carpenter that built most of the initial buildings of the new town of Cody, Wyoming.
Note 6: "Webster" may be William P. Webster (1850-1935), a machinist by trade and Postmaster of Cody in 1897.
Note 7: "The Mormon Carpenter" is not further identified but may have been J. Ross Carpenter (1867-1943), a land developer and president of the Federal Land & Securities Company.
Note 8: "Tom Percell" is Tom Purcell (1854-1900), a saloon owner in Cody, Wyoming.
Note 9: "Newton" is likely Abram C. Newton (1864-1959), a local rancher who invested in the town of Cody, Wyoming, donating logs for building the town.
